description:
I have rate this place more than 5 stars I definitely would 
Look .. I'm a huge fan of Italian food and Italy one of the destinations I want to go to to eat!! 
But I'm lucky enough to have such amazing Italian restaurants near by I can enjoy until I go to Italy :) 
The funny fact is I'm a yelper and usually check places before I go 
But this time was different we were at the beach blanket show close by and after the show we were walking around talking about the show and decided to stop somewhere to eat and we stopped here 
After we sat down I checked my yelp to see what to expect and it was actually pretty good surprise 
The other fact it's the oldest Italian restaurant in the city!! So I made a historical destination .. wow 
Come to important part.. Food 
Man .. food was really really good 
I ordered mushroom risotto with a glass of Italian wine .. I was soooo happy eating that meal 
And to end the night right I ordered a penna cotta for dessert .. out of this world yummy 

Very highly recommended .. perfect! 
If you want a nice Italian food experience
author: Maha M.

description:
Aimed towards an older crowd, food was good, and live music was adorable. 

I came here for a work dinner w/ a couple of my coworkers. And the crowd was def a lot older, even the chef that came out to talk to the partons had a head full of white hair. 

The food was good, very standard Italian food. I got the Sotto Mare, and it was quite good, I think the seafood could have been a little more fresh (being in North Beach and all) but overall it was delicious. In terms of price, it was $30 for the dish, and I finished the whole plate with room to spare for dessert, so it is very pricey. 

Service was good, the waiters joked around with us a lot but were attentive, and the live music was a HUGE plus. That night they had a full 5 person jazz band and it was so much fun (a little loud for us to be able to do business talk, but a lot of fun nonetheless). 

Overall, I don't know if I would come here myself, but this could be a cute place to impress your spouse's grandparents.
author: Sophie W.

description:
We were here Sunday 10/7 for a 6pm reservation. Food was very good. Server was ridiculously slow and not able to keep up. The place was packed and our waiter was swamped. He was short with us and not attentive. We waited so long between getting refills on drinks, then on getting dishes cleared and again to get dessert menu. 
Then, before we asked for the check, we ordered some desserts to go. Another long wait. Check came and went. No desserts. When we asked he said he hadn't charged us for them yet. Seriously? We asked for them before we were given the check. 

Just frustrating. We came here at the request of my dad who was visiting from the east coast. He raved about this place from the last time he was here, 8 years ago. Sadly this visit was lacking. As a San Francisco resident I can tell you I wouldn't recommend after tonight.
author: Keri M.

description:
It's been 132 years, and Fior D'Italia never fail to please every customers.  America's oldest Italian restaurant will continue to live up to its reputation.

I'm glad I used this opportunity on Labor Day to come to Fior D'Italia when it's less crowded.  Just had to call for reservations if I want to have a table.  A guy with a strong Italian accent on a phone wanted me to wait until 1 pm.  But from Michael who happens to be my waiter for the day, he told me it's Gianni, owner of Fior D'Italia.  I'm surprised!  Anyway, Michael is a good American gentleman who's easy to talk to, and took care of me, directed me to the table near the window, where I can watch customers coming into the restaurant.

Don't you just love a fancy restaurant under San Remo Hotel?  A big enough interior space with some black and white paintings of the good old days at Barbara Coast, a big bar at the other side, banquet hall at the back, and some sweet rustic music to relax and enjoy.  The 500 lbs measuring scale outside the restaurant have never been used, but it's never shabby.

Then it was time to choose what's on the small lunch menu.  I barely have a juicy steak since it's only good for dinner.  No need for alcoholic or non-alcoholic beverages, Michael gave me free water refills.  Love a free big piece of crispy ciabatta bread drizzled with virgin olive oil, excluding vinegar.  Here are my three best dishes.

Fior Caesar Salad.  Fresh iceberg lettuce and crunchy croutons topped with Caesar dressing and cheese flakes was the easiest of the leafy green salads.  Picture perfect as it's been seen and tasted!

Linguine with meatball.  How 'bout that?  A classic spaghetti & meatballs topped with tomato sauce.  No need for additional cheese flakes on a childhood favorite dish.  Everything was just right.  For those who are new to spaghetti, here's a chance to learn.  Fork into the noodles, twirl some until it becomes a yarn, and put them in your mouth (no slurping loudly).

Panna Cotta with strawberry sauce.  A bit bigger and more satisfying than the original in a very cute small jar, this should be one of my favorite desserts.  Aside from a raspberry and few blueberries, mint leaves are truly edible.

I wanted to come again "Fior" sure, but I have other eateries I be eager to go to.  I'm positive Fior D'Italia is doing an outstanding job.  Great to be back in the oldies.
author: Jimmy C.

description:
I would say this place is slightly below par. I would say a solid 3.5 stars. Everything is okay, but a bit salty. The calamari and bread are very good actually. Pasta was salty and I did not enjoy it. Meatball was actually pretty bad. 

Dessert was not great, we got two and didn't like either.
author: Tina L.

description:
It's presumably the oldest Italian restaurant in the US (since 1886). We came here on a Thursday evening. The restaurant was very busy when we arrived, but we were able to reserve a table for 5 on the same day.

The ambience is that of an old school Italian restaurant. It definitely felt more neighborly than touristy. If you're old enough, this restaurant could be romantic too. 

They make fresh pasta, but I ended up ordering from the "dry pasta" section of the menu: Bucatini Amatriciana. Bucatini is my favorite pasta, but I was hesitant because why would I order something I make at home all the time? Was I wrong? I was very impressed by their Bucatini Amatriciana, and I was clearly the happiest one at the table. Most of their past dishes (fresh or dry), except for the ones with sea food, are only $17! See their dinner menu here: http://www.fior.com/dinner.

I think this place is great for a family dinner. The ambience is just right (old school but not uptight). The food is great but reasonably priced. There are millions of ok to good Italian restaurants (i.e., 3~4 stars) in the US, but I think Fior d'Italia ranks above them in terms of the quality of food and service, the ambience, and last but not least the pricing.

******************************
If you found something useful in my review, please hit "useful" so that I can improve my reviews. If you love food and traveling, follow me, or better yet, let's become friends on Yelp! Thank you and happy Yelping!
author: Masanori D.

description:
Truly terrible, salty, overpriced, rude service. Hilariously bad.

It's sad to see all the reviews written by shills.

Don't waste your time.
author: Taylor S.

description:
Excellent all around! It was pretty late on a Sunday, so we got right in--not sure if that would be true on other days. Quick, extremely friendly service. Our waiter suggested the rack of lamb, which was amazing. Tender, moist, and perfectly cooked. The sauce was bold, but did. It overpower the lamb (the same is true of the Rosemary seasoning). My wife and 5 year-old son split the cabbage soup and lasagne.

After the lasagne came out (very large portion), she decided to stop eating the soup. It was delicious and rich, with cheese and bread, so she wanted to save room for the lasagne. My son declared it the "best lasagne in the world". He was probably right. Rich but with a strong enough tomato sauce that it didn't cling to the tongue too long.

Before bringing our dessert menu, the waiter cleared our table, and the manger (owner?) came over immediately to see if there was a problem with the soup. My wife explained it was just too much food, and he gave another opportunity and confirmed she shouldn't hold back. It was obvious how much he cared, which was great to see. 

The service from the second we walked in the door to the second we left was superb. By far the best restaurant experience I can remember. The atmosphere, service, and food were all top notch, and it's very hard to find a place that does everything so spot-on.

Thank You!
author: Steve M.

description:
Over a century of delicious food!

Fior d'Italia, or the Flower of Italy, opened its doors on May of 1886 and has been around for 131 years since! Think about it, it was on February of that year when Jesse and Frank James robbed their first bank in Liberty, Missouri!  

Fior d'Italia has moved around six times since its original opening day. Being a resident of North Beach, I remember the night in 2005 when the fire in their last location next to Washington Square Park forced them to eventually move to current location under the historic San Remo Hotel.

The food is delicious, so you can't do much wrong with your choices, but on this particular night we started with Cozze e Vongole con Vino e Aglio or Clams and mussels for appetizer which I washed down with a glass of perfectly mixed vodka martini ("Shaken, not stirred"!!). Delicious, although the juice was slightly too salty for my taste (must admit that I do not care much for salt!). For main course we had Pollo al Mattone (Half chicken flattened and roasted with rosemary and garlic) and Osso Buco con Polenta (Veal shank in stock, carrots, celery, onion and citrus rind served with polenta). I loved the Osso Buco, but must admit that the chicken was far more tasty than what I had hoped for! I mean it, it was delicious! Both entrées came in healthy portions so we were full , but we decided to share an order of Pera Caramellata (Poached Pear with Cream & Caramel). It was heavenly! 

Our server was a young man who may have been a bit new at his job, and I found him to be a bit less attentive as I would have liked. For example, I put in a delayed order of a Pasta e Fagioli soup and asked if he could get it to me before the main course, he said he could, but then they all arrived together, so I had to return the soup. Not a big deal for me personally, but others may expect better service than that.

Altogether, and excellent dining experience for both of us.
author: Afshin A.

description:
Great authentic pasta! Super al dente noodles and excellent sauces. Got the tagliatelle bolognese and it was delicious! One of my favorite pastas and they did it right! Plating could be a little nicer but taste wise was excellent. 

Great ambiance, old school flair meets home cooking. Even the waiters are Italian and speak with accents.

Great place!
author: Melissa L.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here on Thanksgiving and what a treat.  I found this restaurant on Yelp just looking for whatever was open during the holiday.  So much history in this restaurant as it opened in 1886.  I felt like I went back in time.

We arrived at 2:30 and got seated right away.  I made reservations for 2:45, but we actually got there much earlier than expected.

We ordered the calamari, burrata, ravioli di zucca and tortellini.  Everything was amazing and tasted fresh.  Though the ravioli was good, it was a little bland for me even after adding salt and parmesan cheese.  The tortellini was so delicious!
author: Rachel L.

description: I found this restaurant by just walking by. I got lured in by the fact that it says it is the oldest Italian restaurant in the country. Food was ok. I just had a salad and some calamari. I did just sit at the bar on an early afternoon so I really don't know what the true dining experience is actually like. If I ever come back, I will provide an update to this post.
author: Darnell M.

description:
My friend decided to have her birthday dinner here since she loves pasta. The location was great, parking was kin of hard depending on time and what day you go. We did get a bit confused going in as we went into the wrong door which was to the bar but we just had to walk over and get checked in. The restaurant was spacious and we were seated right away. 

For starters we all shared a calamari basket, and a dozen oysters. The calamari was great and plentiful, definitely a lot to go around. It was cooked right and wasn't chew at all to my liking. The oysters were not the best, I've had better. Maybe because the oysters were HUGE, and I tend to like them smaller if I am going to eat them raw. I also didn't think I tasted as fresh as I thought, and then again its to my liking but I've def had better. 

For my entrée I ordered the seafood linguine, while my friends ordered the meatsauce over spaghetti, and some ordered the risotto. I have to say I was not a HUGE fan of the pasta either. I felt that my seafood was just throw in there and cooked, my pasta sauce tasted a bit watery and the pasta was over cooked. The risotto didn't even look like risotto, it looked like porridge and I couldn't taste anything. I have to say the meatsauce over spaghetti was good but that was probably the only thing. 

All in all service was great, and food came out in a timely manner but I wasn't impressed and im a HUGE pasta fan. Perhaps we came on a off day but I wasn't super excited about the dishes we ordered and it didn't seem to have any flavor.
author: Tiffany K.

description: We dined here for lunch. Everything in "The oldest Italian Restaurant in the US" lived up to its hype. This beautifully maintained restaurant was impeccable. The black and white photos showing events past made the ambiance that much better and shared its historical flair. The tables are beautifully preset. Our server was polite and friendly. Their bread had the perfect crust and was paired with the table olive oil and basalmic vinegar. The food requires only one word...DELICIOUS!  Our order for three consisted of the bruschetta salad, the pumpkin raviolis, the tortellini in creme sauce and the sausage with polenta. Of course we had to try their tiramisu as well!  Kudos Fior to your excellence!  We will be back!
author: Taffy L.

description:
Decided to try this place, claimed to be America's oldest Italian restaurant, in little Italy mainly because the thumbnail for the restaurant had a pasta trio that looked delicious. I always get indecisive at new places because i want to try everything. And this menu had it all. Luckily they still had the dish, even though it wasn't on the menu! 

Three pastas, gnocchi with red sauce, chicken stuffed pasta in Alfredo, and a tube pasta in a creamy pesto sauce they were all equally delicious!!! I also had the house cab, which was so smooth!!

We also had the bruschetta appetizer which was very flavorful! 

My girlfriend, who is trying to eat less gluten, got the egg noodle pasta with red meat sauce, which was a flavor sensation! 
And free hot bread and oil and vinegar as you wait. 

Great neighborhood with street parking close by, awesome interior and atmosphere, frank Sinatra playing over speakers, and prompt professional service. 

Would definitely go back to this place to try other dishes, or get the trio again! They even had these tasty little gummy eucalyptus mints that were very powerful!
author: Brock M.

description:
This was an excellent experience!  

We came here a few years ago and remembered it as being a great meal and great service.  This visit did not disappoint.

The Maî·tre D' was phenomenal.  Very welcoming and making sure our table was ready for us, urbane and pleasant!

Our server was slightly more reserved, but wonderful, none the less.  I love the traditional feel of the restaurant with the white tablecloths and separate bar area and appreciated it's history as one of the oldest Italian restaurants in the country.

They bring crispy italian bread to the table with olive oil.  We started with the Caeser Salad which is traditional with that slight tang of anchovy.  I had a different salad with fruit and nuts in it which was delicious but I can't remember the name of it.  

I had the Ravioli de Zucca (pumpkin) and it was plump and sweet/savory deliciousness.  The Trenette al Pesto was really good as well.  It said egg pasta, and it was almost as thin as vermicelli, but it was flat and cooked perfectly.  We enjoyed sharing bites because the flavors were so good together.  

I would definitely recommend this restaurant to anyone, but do call for reservations as they get very busy and don't take reservations through Yelp or Open Table at this time.
author: Melanie E.

description:
Came here with a group of 17.  We were in the private dining room in the back.  The decor is old school Italy, and the food is similar.  The menu is filled with traditional Italian fare.

I got the escargot and Tortellini alla Panna.  The escargot was scalding hot, but not bad.  The pasta dish was a bit bland, it needed seasoning.  However the portion was huge and I was able to share some with the rest of my party.  

Overall, it was a fun night, and although the food isn't that memorable, it was reasonably priced.  Service was good.
author: paul b.

description: After eating at several Italian restaurants in San Francisco, I've found my favorite. The ambiance is all you would expect from a proper Italian restaurant. The service is fantastic from start to finish. I had the Tignanello 2014, linguini tutto mare (seafood pasta)and it was perfect. When in San Francisco... it's a must.
author: Matt H.

description:
Five years ago we were watching the Travel Channel.
Fior d'Italia was showcased.  We decided to go to San Francisco to try the food at the restaurant.  SO GLAD WE DID.  Since then, every time we visit the City and we want to eat Italian food Fior d'Italia is our spot. 

Pasta is always cooked perfectly. The sauces are delicious, creamy when needed. The meatballs are delicious and moist. Veal is an ingredient:-) The rabbit osso buco is YUM! I also really enjoy the Ravioli di Zucca (Ravioli stuffed with pumpkin, amaretti and mustard fruit, butter, pine nuts and sage sauce). E' delizioso!!!

Service is very good. Ambience is very comfortable, yet formal. Very nice. The restaurant reminds you of years past. Very nostalgic. 

Fior d'Italia is a beautifully delicious flower d'Italia. Flower of Italy :-)). E' un ristorante per tutti! It's a restaurant for everyone :-))

Bon appetite y Buona notte!!!
author: Eliza J.

description: All I can say is YUM! A nice restaurant in a historic location.  Great food and service, too!  Would definitely recommend, and will definitely go back there.  Prices were reasonable (we had seven people, and the bill was $210 - that's with three of the four adults having drinks).  There's an odd little city healthcare tax that this restaurant chooses to add to the final tab (it's optional), but hey, if it helps provide healthcare for SF kids and the poor, then I'm ok with that! (I think it was about $12 in our bill.)  walking distance to the wharf - and the seals lol.  Just....GO!
author: Leesha A.

description:
We were looking for a eating place where we could get some vegetarian food since my husband is a pure vegetarian. After looking at a bunch of restaurants that mostly were seafood, we chose Fior D'Italia since it is Italian and you do have some choices of vegetarian food. The decor is very old school and laid back. In my opinion, it needs a bit of upgrade and maintenance. The floors creak when you walk and the carpet looked quite dirty. Apparently, it is one of the oldest Italian restaurants in the United States. Might as well hold the position high! 

Once we were seated, we were served with some complimentary bread along with olive oil and balsamic vinegar that were already on the table. I'm not sure if the bread was supposed to be that way but it was quite rough in texture. We were in for some light dinner and chose Caesar salad and Tortellini alla Panna. I don't think there is any way to mess up the salad so it was nice but the Tortellini was very bland. My palate was craving for some spice and all I got was cheese! May be this dish was prepared well but I didn't like it. Some other dish might have been good considering it has 300+ 4 star reviews. Will try something else if we land here again.
author: Harshada K.

description: Old school since 1886. I love eating at historic establishments and this place is a must visit. We ate on a Wednesday night and had no reservations but I would recommend you make them just in case it gets busy. The good food, service, music, and atmosphere is what you will receive when you come here, I highly recommend it. Skip the nasty Olive Garden and come here for a better experience.
author: Franklin M.

description:
Excellent, traditional, and a no brained if you have never been here. Pasta salads wine and dessert all on point here. Our party had
  Alfredo, gnocchi, penne, lasagna, and risotto. Dessert double chocolate mousse and terramissu. Bottle of red.. exquisite..thanks again fior..
author: Dan W.

description: Made reservations here for my son's birthday dinner. Just a note, it was warm in there. My son had the rabbit and loved it. My veal chop was cooked to perfection but the veggies were hard and crunchy. My husband enjoyed his chicken. The bread you get is so good especially dipped in the oil and balsamic on the table. Only thing is my son was super disappointed he really wanted tiramisu for dessert and they were out! For days he wanted it. I felt bad. He ended up with the mousse. It was ok. I had a cannoli, good but the filling was loose.  My husband had gelato. Beware the service is slow. And not easy to flag down your waiter.
author: Jen B.

description:
Very solid old school Italian place. I hoped for that when was getting my reservation, and that's exactly what we've got. Yes, our waiter spoke Italian, too. 
Extremely nice ambiance and decor. Menu is impressive, and food is good but not outstanding. Just right to put honest 4 stars mark.
author: Boris V.

description:
Terrible service. The wait staff made it seem like we were troubling them when we were placing our orders, asking for an extra plate etc. 

The food itself was actually pretty decent. The Bolognese was correctly done al dente which is a nice change. 

However the service alone killed the experience completely. I would actively recommend people don't eat here.
author: Jeremy G.

description: Great food and excellent service. Personalized service in a very busy city. Will definitely come again.
author: Kriss S.

description:
Checked out this place after seeing it on the travel channel and found it to be every bit as true as advertised. I'm a big risotto fan and have to say the mushroom risotto was the best I ever had....in fact I wanted to order a 2nd despite being full. Even dreamt about it afterwards...it was that good. Their wine selection was great too. Loved their pinot noir.

Was surprised to see a few reviews mentioning poor service. I was impressed by their excellent service despite us bringing 3 toddlers. I guess if you give respect you get respect.

I can see why it's the oldest Italian restaurant in the US. They perfected their craft and have been proven through the test of time. Definitely will be back next time I'm in SF.
author: David E.

description:
Oh my, Fior d'Italia takes me back to the day when I was a young innocent who would only eat at a place like this with a dozen other people. That's because it was considered fancy eating for someone barely making enough to keep warm in a studio apartment. It used to be where Original Joe's is now across from Washington Square Park, but for the past decade, it's been up a few blocks on Mason in the San Remo Hotel. After passing by it, usually after a hearty meal at Albona around the corner, Jamie W. and I finally tried it just before Christmas, and it brought back warm memories of my penny-saving youth. The prices are still not bad by San Francisco standards.

Anyway, we were seated toward the back of the dining room as a jazz ensemble was finishing up near the front window (photo: http://bit.ly/2j9z6XO). There was quite an audience of enraptured regulars singing and snapping along with the Christmas swing standards the band played. We enjoyed it from where we were but honestly focused primarily on the menu. A big hunk of rustic sourdough bread landed on our table which we surrounded with quite a pool of olive oil and red wine vinegar (photo: http://bit.ly/2imF1I5). For a starter, we didn't go wrong with the $16 Burrata con Pomodori Basilico e Olio (Burrata with Tomato, Basil and Virgin Olive Oil) (photo: http://bit.ly/2j9FBtr).

Very fresh mozzarella surrounded by tomato slices and olives resting on basil leaves with a bit of frisee on top. Delicious. We also did well with our pasta entrees. Jamie had the $17 Tagliatelle alla Bolognese which was eggy with just the right amount of meat sauce to satisfy a true carnivore who would otherwise bypass the bistecca (photo: http://bit.ly/2ja9cU6). I went for the more luxuriant $17 Tortellini alla Panna stuffed with chicken and swimming a bit in lighter-than-expected cream sauce (photo: http://bit.ly/2j3f9jq), Thank goodness we ordered the $12 Funghi di Selva Trifolati, a medley of three wild mushroom sauteed in olive oil, garlic, and parsley (photo: http://bit.ly/2imy0a6).

I quickly mixed it up with the tortellini to enhance my dish (photo: http://bit.ly/2jm8rEM). We ended our meal with the $7 Tiramisu alla Schiuma. which is a mousse-style tiramisu served in a sundae glass and sprinkled with a bit of espresso powder (photo: http://bit.ly/2jGBnuv). With a straight cup of coffee (photo: http://bit.ly/2imHlPf), it provided just the right finale as the ensemble had already packed up and went home. Funny how this place has relocated several times in the past 130 years, but somehow it maintains the same vibe of conviviality and attentive service I recall from oh-so-many years ago. Good to rediscover a San Francisco institution and still be able to recommend it.

FOOD - 4 stars...classic Italian fare, well remembered, still well executed
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...big space, enough for a jazz combo and tables of fans
SERVICE - 4 stars...young waiter who respects old traditions
TOTAL - 4 stars...definitely worthwhile to come back to a proven North Beach spot
author: Ed U.

description:
I think there are people who will be drawn to this restaurant and love it no matter what any Yelp review says  because of two main reasons:

1. Your family went to some iteration of this restaurant before you were born and they will still be going after you no longer have a seat at the table at this or any other establishment.
2. You are so enamored with the nostalgic trip the place offers that objective reality holds no space in your head.

Meanwhile....people who wander in because they are seduced by the "oldest Italian restaurant in CA, America, the World" mythologies, or the reviews on Yelp or because they are staying in a nearby hotel will find the place dingy with bland poorly presented food served by waiters who size you up as worthy or not worthy of their attention soon after you are seated - no matter what the defenses of the other group of Fior D'Italia fans.

Our party of two at this restaurant held one of each of these (perhaps overly generalized) types of patrons. 

I could see the issues with the restaurant - scuffed up chairs, flies we had to fight off from our food (the front door was open the entire time we were there), plates of food that would get marked down on the TV show "Chopped" due to dull presentation and flavor profiles that are rooted in the 1960's or earlier. But for me - it was all part of the charm - and I thought the food was good enough to enjoy, if not remember weeks from now. The bread was excellent; the appetizer with grilled shrimp, a small caprese salad and prosciutto and melon was tasty. My pasta pesto dish was not much to write about - but I added lemon from the appetizer plate and suddenly I really really liked it.

My friend meanwhile ate two bites of her meat filled ravioli, declared that it tasted like dog food, and sat looking around the restaurant for the next 30 minutes becoming increasingly thirsty and miserable as, undeniably,  the waiter ignored our two top for the tables of four and six that were seated after us. 

In the end...I have no recommendation to anyone about Fior D'Italia except to say - search your culinary soul before entering.
author: Dawn B.

description: The main courses was good. Stay away from the balsamic they give at the table and the service is really very slow. We got there at 5:45 and didn't get out until 8:30.
author: Jm C.

description: We picked this restaurant from Yelp while visiting SFO for a few days and we weren't disappointed - on the contrary! When we entered we were happily surprised to find a swing, ragtime, early 20th century jazz band made up of excellent musicians. They play on Sunday afternoons and Wednesday nights. It has to be one of the best evening I had in a long, long time. Add good food - we chose the fresh pasta - and good wine with a great tiramisu to cap it all. Perfect evening.
author: Kathy V.

description: Like a Seinfeld episode, we ate here because we found a parking spot. Best thing that could have happened. We left Bastille Day across from Ferry building craving Italian food. Started circling Washington square and as our distance from the the square got greater and greater I parked at first empty spot. While looking at yelp, I noticed an old looking building that appeared to be a bar or restaurant, If was both. I entered the wrong door as usual, a distinguished older gent in jeans and a blazer welcomed us and walked us to the dining room, it was packed. We were seated in a nice size table with a spare chair for my Panama hat(thank God). We ordered Caesar salad, calamari and Lasagna Bolognese. Service was excellent, food was good. My only complaint was the waiter kindly split our dish of lasagna but failed to mention the baking dish was 300 degrees. I unwittingly touched the plate and the pain shot to my brain faster than lightning. I quickly warned my wife to not touch the plate. Very nice experience overall, when craving Italian food I will return to Fior D'Italia
author: Michael A.

description: The service is very old school...unpolished but they keep it real and let the food and historical significance speak for itself. It has historical charm and we saw several guests having a romantic time. The food was classic. Middle of the road...wouldn't come back but happy we were able to check it off our list.
author: Megan H.

description: Great old school Italian atmosphere, it feels like you are dining at Al Capone's favorite restaurant. The cold meats antispasto is very authentic and delicious. The pasta was FANTASTIC!
author: Priscilla S.

description: Came with some friends on a Sunday night.  Not busy at all.  I had the lamb chops, which were very good, however, the sauce was a bit lacking.  One friend had the osso buco.  He thought it was meh.  I tasted it, and agreed that it needed seasoning and wasn't fully tender.  I also noticed that it was served with instant polenta - a big no-no for me!  Another friend had the butternut ravioli and loved it, while another friend had the chicken. I suspect what they do best here is the pasta.  Service was good.
author: Paul W.

description:
When we arrived at FdI for our 2pm reservation on Christmas Day, the host told us we had no reservation although I had made it several weeks prior using Open Table.  Then he claimed to find the reservation but said it was at 2:30pm. Umm,no it was for 2pm.After several minutes of confusion he seated us at the lone booth in the bar, not even one of the dining rooms. We received abysmal service and our meal took over two hours due to the slow service. When you're outside the dining room you tend to receive short shrift and that's what happened.

Would love to know why the host lied to us.

We won't be returning.
author: .Hon H.

description: Food and atmosphere are amazing. The oldest Italian restaurant in America is right downstairs from the hotel where we stay while visiting the city. I highly recommend both places. Whatever you order will be delicious but get an order of the rosemary potatoes as a side dish - you won't regret it.
author: Gary R.

description:
This place was packed but we managed to get a table rather quickly. 

Trendy looking place. The service was quick and attentive. The food came out promptly and was very hot. We ordered the caesar, roasted cauliflower, and margherita with hot salami pizza.  All good and very tasty. 

Will definitely return.  Lots of other food on the menu that we'd love to try!
author: A T.

description:
Heavenly!  From the table bread, to the appetizers, to entre, and dessert!  Every trip to San Fran will include a dinner here! My mom and niece shared a minestrone soup and the Fettucini Alfredo and added chicken breast to it. Devine!
I had the Pesto Chicken (forgot the fancy Italian name)...again devine! 
We shared the shrimp wrapped in prucetta and The calamari.  Both good though the shrimp were also devine! 
I am harsh on food and ALL of it was SO tasty here! 
Must try!!!
Only one photo of my nearly gone chicken pesto with the chicken Alfredo in the background. Oh and I have a sweet wine tooth and the Mia was delish!!! 
Our server was Michael! He gets 5 stars too, even though he had to deliver the news of them being out of chocolate mousse!!
author: Aixa D.

description: Very accommodating staff providing attentive, informative, and knowledgeable service. I had the Ravioli Bolognese and the sauce was well -seasoned and simmer to perfection. The ladies had Paglia e Fieno con Piselli and the New York strip-Lombata di Manzo in Padella Pepata. They were very pleased with their selections, but covetous of mine. All of the dishes were well-prepared, beautifully presented, and absolutely delicious. The meal was paired nicely with a bottle of Ruffino Riserva Ducale Gold Chianti Classico. I highly recommend this classic Italian gem of a restaurant.
author: Daniel B.

description: Oldest continually operating Italian restaurant in America. Since 1886. Calamari Fritte was on point, they made mussels marinara for us, even though not on the menu. Service was slow, but they were good. Manager did a great job eyeballing the guests. He picked up on the slow service by watching me and got the server over to us. Live jazz band on a Sunday afternoon. The whole staff loved my kids. Cool photos, old menus from throughout history. Nice seeing that breakfast cost 30 cents in 1935. Definitely recommend.
author: Dallas V.

description:
We really wanted to like this place, but our waiter was so rude to us. He did all he could to usher us out as soon as possible. We sat down, ordered, and the food came out practically 5 minutes later, when other people who had sat down much earlier were still enjoying their bread appetizer. We're still puzzled as to why this happened -- it was so obviously rude and we felt uncomfortable experiencing this treatment. 

My friend got the fresh Tagliatelle alla Bolognese and I think she enjoyed it. I had the Bucatini. The spicy tomato sauce was great, but the pancetta was disappointing: most of it seemed to be straight fat. 

I sincerely hope all future customers are treated with equal care. At the very least, we expect professionalism from the staff.
author: Julia Y.

description:
More like a 3.5....

Pro- They have happy hour everyday!

Con-They no longer offer happy hour prices for food:(

Came here last year for the first time and loved their happy hour! That was kindof the "sell" of the place. Everyday happy hour 4-6. We came here before beach blanket babylon and had a blast. At that time, Happy hour dishes were about $5, and all wines and wells were 1/2 off! They were also dog friendly previously and had dog treats hanging in the front!

Fast forward to fathers day this year and things were a bit different-no dog treats on the atio for our dog. We (5 of us) ordered a bunch of plates to share. We love the pizza bread, calamari, and brushetta. My family really liked the veal ravioli but I think it tastes like chef boyardee! not my fave.

I think the happy hour app plates are good for 2 to share, but there was hardly enough on each plate for 5 of us to each get taste. They are smaller than regular size forsure. The Salami plate was particular disappointing and small. I think some of the happy hour plates would be worth $9 (Calamari and raviolis) but the pizza bread and the salami plate were not worth $9. We ordered full size caesar salad and pesto pasta- both good. Bread was brought to the table only when asked.

I think the half off wines are pretty cool... each glass ran between 7-10 bucks with discount. 

Service was attentive and fast. Waters were refilled. I just think it was better when apps were discounted. The food is not the most authentic italian but its good for happy hour/bar italian!

Check for 5 adults to share a handful of happy hour dishes and some of us drinking half off wine (not all)= $160 with tip.
author: Erica D.

description:
Average Italian fare with above average service.

We came in early and the chef was nice enough to prepare a dish that was off-menu (Chicken Piccata instead of veal). The food was OK. The service, however, was excellent and the ambiance was nice in an "old school" kind of way.

With so many italian places to try in SF, It's not likely we'll be back anytime soon; but we're glad we gave "Americas oldest Italian restaurant" a try.
author: Aaron M.

description: This was an unexpectedly elegant dining experience with old world charm. It has been in operation for 132 years. On the night we went, there was a terrific jazz band which really added to the ambiance. Service was great! We had osso bucco, spinach fettuccine with lobster (that night's special), tortellini with cream sauce, and ravioli with bolognese sauce. All of it was delicious, including the wine. We finished with coffee and tiramisu. The food was authentic Italian cuisine and thoroughly enjoyable. It was a delightful evening!
author: Holly G.

description: Most authentic Italian restaurant in NB. Calamari is the best I've had. My fiancé and I love coming here for the great service and food. I highly recommend their lasagna.
author: Garrett S.

description: Wow. Go here! If you are staying at Fisherman's Wharf, you absolutely must go here. The food is fantastic, the service is fantastic. My son has to order chicken parmesana at every Italian resteraunt he goes to, an though it was not on the menu, the made it for him specially.  He said it was perfection.
author: Ger H.

description: Oh. My. God. The best Italian food I've ever had by far. I ordered the fettuccine Alfredo and it was absolutely breathtaking. The presentation, the scent, the flavour, it was just gorgeous. Absolutely authentic Italian. I would go a million times if I could
author: Kayle R.

description:
We came here this past weekend for my father's birthday as it was walking distance to Cobb's Comedy Club.  Parking in the city can be a little tricky but there was plenty of street parking near the restaurant.  Fior d'Italia is the oldest Italian restaurant in the city so you know they're executing the classics beautifully.  

What we ordered:
Calamari, Risotto, Ravioli, Halibut, and Half Chicken.  The half chicken was everyone's favorite at the table.  My order was the Risotto, which was very oily.  It seemed to be missing a little something so I added some chicken into it from my mom's giant order of the half chicken and it was prefect.  Because we were celebrating a birthday they brought out a scoop of ice cream with a candle for my father which was a nice touch.
author: Stacey C.

description:
From start to finish, our dining experience was top notch. The maitre'd was so charming and it was totally genuine. He made every table feel like a VIP. I witnessed him run outside to pick a purple flower and present it to a women who appeared to be around 90 years old. A family celebrating a graduation was given a private room (without making prior reservations). We love jazz and were given the best seats in the house to watch the show. 

We recently discovered this establishment a few weeks ago from The Food Network or the Travel Channel. I'm so glad we made it a point to visit. 

Here's what we ordered:

Caesar salad, pumpkin ravioli (the official name is much fancier) and fettuccine Alfredo. I could eat their salad every day/all day. As far as the pasta dishes go, I prefer the fettuccine over the ravioli, but they were both delicious. I knew that the ravioli would be both sweet and savory, but the sage and pine nuts were a little bit overwhelming. 

Anytime I'm in The City, I'll make it a point to come back -especially on a Sunday or Wednesday for the awesome jazz.
author: Latoya R.

description: Wonderful Italian food, the meat sauce is thick and rich. The service is fantastic and the interior of the restaurant is lovely. Cool jazz background music too!
author: Chris L.

description:
OMG!!!! 
Ok, FIRST... the smell when you are still outside. It's like actually being in Italy. This is what an Italian restaurant should smell like... heaven. Absolute heaven. 
Then you walk in. The jazz band. What a cool evening.  We are vacationing for our 20th wedding anniversary. We could not have had a better evening. (Thank you to the people from Washington who recommended it!!) we were seated immediately without a reservation, to a great table. Alberto brought water and bread within seconds and kept our glasses full. (Very nice after walking around so much today!!) the Octavio helped us with our selections. Everything was UH-MAZINGLY delicious!!! The barrata salad was the creamiest I've ever had. Hubby had a prawn dish. (Absolutely delicious- the only thing that would've made it better was some fresh fettuccine) he said the flavor was incredible. I ordered a chicken with  pancetta and fontina cheese. Wonderful flavor and very tender. We both would order this again. Hubby ordered tiramisu. (I'm low carb or I would've eaten it too) he said it was delicious and not too sweet. I had a house Chianti that I really enjoyed.  I could not have asked for a better 20th anniversary dinner. Thank you!!!
author: Caressa G.

description: This place is incredible. The food is like in Italy.  I am so impressed.  The service is impeccable.  The bread is to die for. I sat down and didn't look at the menu. I wanted chicken parmigiana.  It wasn't on the menu.  They made it special.  It was phenomenal.  I can't wait to come back.  Great experience!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Todd A.

description: Absolute 5 star restaurant. Loved the incredible old school Italian feel of this place, especially for dinner. The dining room on a Saturday evening had a 5 piece band playing! That is something that I rarely see in restaurants anymore! While I only came for happy hour, I am already planning a trip for dinner. The patio was a great place to sit outside and have some beverages (50% during happy hour!) Additionally, the bar menu is extensive, and we had many delicious eats including ravioli and mussels. I have to say, they provided excellent service. Fior d'Italia is a very classic establishment who does it right.
author: Mary Kate R.

description: Had the lasagne with a side of spinach. Very nice interior. Waiters well dressed. My wife ordered the cabbage and sausage soup but was brought the wrong soup. Waiter went and placed the right soup order right away. Lasagna was very good and the spinach was excellent. I have been here before and will be back. No wine or dessert for us this time.
author: C W.

description: Was recommended to this place by the Hotel Zephyr, and did not disappoint. Super cute little old Italian place. Fresh made pastas, entrees, everything sounded amazing. They did offer a gluten free pasta, but I went the mushroom risotto. DID NOT REGRET THAT DECISION. The risotto was sooooo good. Just a few blocks up from the tourist warf and totally worth it.
author: Sarah D.

description: Authentic, delicious Italian cuisine. I've ordered the gnocchi twice and it's been great! Highly recommend.
author: Alea N.

description: One of the most classy and authentic Italian restaurants in north beach.  Very low key and intimate.  The staff is excellent and inviting. Never left unsatisfied.  White table cloth old school feel.  Great place.
author: Mark P.

description: Service was rushed and had unpleasant waiter even though I came in half hour before closing and they cancelled my open table reservation after I was already seated (found out later.) So didnt get my points even though I dined at the restaurant.
author: Amit B.

description: I have revisited Fior and found that they have a fabulous happy hour (until 6p). Perfect for chillin after work. I have been back a couple of times and their small $9 plates during happy hour is quite a deal. Music on Sunday afternoons are a plus. I felt compelled to update my review.
author: Googie G.

description:
It would be easy to say that being the "oldest Italian restaurant in America" is as notable as this restaurant gets.  But, it wouldn't be accurate.  

Fior has long been a north beach institution.  Long gone from its original location on Washington Square (where Original Joe's is now), there's no doubt they miss the old spot & the old days since relocating here.  We all do.

The good news is, while they lost the park view, they gained a special bar.  This bar is beautiful & loaded w SF history.  This is the San Remo Hotel building after all...w all that entails. 

But, the best part might be film and rock & roll related.  Back in the 90's, a little movie about north beach was made.  It's aptly titled "Little City," & it covered everything about the old north beach culture.  Chefs, bartenders, the roommate element, green chartreuse...everything.  The kicker?  It was in this restaurant space (before it was Fior) where they filmed the bartending scenes.  Right at this very bar.  

The real kicker?  Jon Bon Jovi starred as the bartender.  

Jon. Bon. Jovi.

As w all tourist spots, neighborhood, iconic, or otherwise, the food can be hit or miss.  My favorite forever here has been the butternut squash ravioli.  It's straight up delicious, & has never let me down.  

For a neighborhood Italian meal...uncrowded & quiet, Fior is perfect.  

4 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description:
Saturday, July 30, 2017
Between 3:30 and 4 p.m.

My spouse O and I arrived at Fior d' Italia (Fd'I) after the 2 p.m. matinee of Beach Blanket Babylon. Since this was our first time at the new location on Mason, in fact, I didn't know until recently that Fd'I had reopened after the fire of 2005. As soon as I saw it is still in existence, I have been craving Spaghetti Amatriciana.

My introduction to the spicy Amatriciana sauce was twenty or more years ago when Fd'I was located on Washington Square. Amatriciana is what I ordered on my first visit to Fd'I and the only dish ordered there until the fire mentioned above. 

I love spicy food, and this sauce packed quite a punch. In fact, I was amazed that an Italian restaurant in California would serve a sauce so heavily laced with cayenne and pepper flakes. It turned my face a Marinara-red, and I had to wipe the sweat from my brow, but with my Cajun roots prevailing, I relished every bite. I've learned since that this sauce isn't always easy to find on the menus of other Italian restaurants, but when it was listed, nothing else on the menu matters, I know what I'm having. But I never found a restaurant that could satisfy my palate with a spicy Amatriciana like that from the kitchen of Fd'I.

O and I  arrived for an early dinner, around 4:00 p.m. The jazz band was playing to a small but enthusiastic audience of diners. It was the lull between lunch and dinner. We were greeted and escorted to our table by a pleasant and swarthily attractive host. As we followed our dishy host,  I delighted in the sound of the creaking floors and live jazz. This restaurant occupies the ground floor of one of the city's oldest hotels, The San Remo, a proud Victorian Italianate, and I would have been extremely disappointed had the walk to our table been without creaks. Some of us cling desperately to the remaining charm in San Francisco, and this is the kind of Victorian splendor we find intoxicating.

To me, this space seemed brighter than the former Washington Square location, but it is certainly not without charm. On our visit, it was a gloriously sunny afternoon in North Beach, so the large window that looks out onto Mason behind Leon Oakley's band filled the dining room with light. 

Another gorgeous, swarthy young man appeared with a big basket of bread. Paradiso! We found Paradiso! It was abundantly clear that we were in for a titillating dining experience. I didn't ask the young man's name because I'm far too old and way too shy so I'll call him, Roman. O and I each ordered the Venesia Martinis, aka Trixie's, from Roman off the House Cocktail Menu and proceeded to enjoy the bread.

The bread was exactly what I expect from an Italian restaurant: rustic, crispy crust and moist and flavorful inside. If you don't hear a sound and if it doesn't make a huge crumbly mess when you tear into Italian bread, well, just open a bag of Wonder and knock yourself out. Fd'I's pane hit the mark. Bull's Eye!

One sip of the Venezia Martini and O and I were hooked! It came with a slice of marinated pear that was, well, sublime. We asked Roman about the pear, he smiled (and what a smile) like he had heard this before and said we might want to try it later in a house-made dessert which turned out to be Pera Caramellata with Passito di Pantelleria. Roman could have sold me the Coliseum and a Ferrari factory-slash-garlic-farm in Gilroy. We had planned to switch to wine with our meal, but there was no way I wasn't going to order another Trixie and O felt the same.

I was enjoying a bowl of Minestrone and O a Cesar Salad when Roman appeared, like a vision with 6 o'clock shadow, Bucatini Amatriciana in hand. I place an order for two more Trixies. Sorry, Bacchus.

And the jazz played on.

Okay, the Amatriciana was not as I remembered. It was far less spicy. But I believe this is because people with sensitive palates dismissed the descriptive word "spicy" on the menu, ordered it then after the first bite, likely complained, some fainted and some, I suspect sued. So, of course, they had to tone it down. But it was still better than I'd had at other restaurants.  Next time, I'll ask Roman if he can crank the heat up a notch or two and I'm sure he'll accommodate.

Dessert: Pera Caramellata with Passito di Pantelleria. Have it!

What a marvelous dining experience. The service, the music, the food and the cocktails, the seven o'clock shadow, the decor and the history... Fior d' Italia remains my favorite Italian restaurant in the city.

Check it out. Buon appetito! 

Grazie, Roman!
author: Julian J.

description: I had the bread, cheese and cabbage soup to start and it was amazing. After that i had the gnocchi and it was a little over cooked. With a decent atmosphere I would come back again to try other items on the menu.
author: Michael H.

description: Worst customer service  so far.. kept us waiting on purpose.  No olive oil at table kept us waiting even after asking.. no plate for the 3rd person at table even after reminding twice. Need to check the food now. Just came here due to glowing reviews, don't think will recommend this to our friends
author: Pradnya N.

description:
My wife and I ate here on our last night in San Francisco. We loved the family feel of the restaurant, history as the oldest Italian restaurant in town and of course the delicious meal we were served (Lasagna and Cesar salad was the bomb).

Highly recommend!
author: Jeff P.

description:
I was so looking forward to returning to a restaurant that I had gone to in my youth.  We started with the caesar salad which was good but that was the end of what I felt was not only a mediocre meal but also not worth the price.  I order the flattened chicken.  This was the driest chicken I have ever had.  The only way that I was able to get the down was with the sauce that covered the chicken.  The rotisserie chicken  I have purchased as grocery stores are 10x's more moist.

If this is what I can now expect I don't think I will be back.  So sad and disappointed to return to an icon of North Beach and a favorite from my youth to a very disappointing meal.
author: Sue P.

description: This is my local neighborhood spot, great happy hour, great food, friendly neighbors and awesome staff!!
author: Allison S.

description:
Over the years I've eaten at FDI many times, however since I don't travel for my business any longer, I've not been since 2003. Btw, FDI, is the oldest operating Italian restaurant I'm SF, & I believe in the entire US?  

So there I am, having a problem recognizing the restaurant, location, anything, so I ask our host why is everything so different?  Well come to find out the old location on Union by the park, burnt down & it's also under new ownership! Who said, things never seem to change!!

Ok back to the review. There menu, mostly northern Italian fair & very good. The service top notch. The restaurant is roomy and has a nice bar as well. Saturday early evening they have a blue's/jazz combo playing till a think 7?

A 4 out of 5 stars.
author: Alan B.

description:
I'm used to the red-sauce Italian restaurants in NYC. There are many in the touristy areas of NY, and the service and food tends to reflect the quick turnaround of these restaurants.

When my mom suggested trying out this restaurant, I automatically assumed it was one of those long-time restaurants that was known more for its name and history than its food.

Wrong - this is a fantastic place. The service was attentive and reflective of a high-end restaurant, and the food was delicious. I had a tasty fish broth-prepared risotto, and shared calamari and burrata with my family. The desserts were excellent as well.
author: Jeffrey L.

description:
Came here for a company event. Amazing food and ambience--live band! The food and vino were first rate. I had the sole: savory if not divine. The veggies were cooked to perfection--thank you!--none of this pretentious undercooked "it's done" nonsense.  The vino was expectedly wonderful and at an appropriate temperature--again, thank you, not "room temperature" warm/hot. 

Bottom line: Destination restaurant
author: Thomas T.

description:
We were recommended this restaurant by our hotel and as the oldest Italian restaurant in the US I expected more quality than what we got. The place is nice on the inside but right away after we ordered our drinks it seemed like everything started going south. I generally drink water and my companion had iced tea which he switched for a Coke since he said it was terrible and then there was a bug in my water..yuck. The bread was actually very good but the Pasta fajole was disappointing and not to my liking. 

We waited about 25 mins for our main course and I noticed that the waiter Gil was not as friendly to us and not focusing at all on our table like he was other parties. He was always busy attending to the other tables and it seemed like we were almost not there. I don't know if it was because we were the only party of 2 (not as big of a bill) and all the other tables had at least 4 or more people so he didn't want to spend time on us (bigger tip). Because of this we were constantly waiting for drinks and even got our food after others who we ordered before. When we finally got our food the waiter asked if we wanted fresh Parmesan, we said yes and he took about 10 mins to bring it because he decided to take a large tables drink order and bring them their drinks before bringing us the cheese for our pasta that was getting cold..SMH.

I ordered the spinach pasta with peas and it was actually very light and fresh tasting. I enjoyed the plate but don't plan on returning. The service is just as important as the food and when the service is this poor it really ruins the experience.
author: Juliana J.

description: Very polite and kind staff. Food was delicious. Very glad I came. You can chose the bar or the spacious dining area. Very quiet and relaxing. We ordered the plate that has 1/2 portions of 3 different pastas. Will return
author: Eric T.

description:
Came for dinner and definite pros and cons, though mostly pros.

Pros- seated quickly by hostess who greeted us as soon as we walked in the door. Sat down and was immediately brought water, olive oil and balsamic. Waiter was efficient and came to take our drink order in a timely manner. While we waited, warm bread slices were placed on our bread plates. Our appetizers and salad came out within 15 - 20 minutes. The prosciutto wrapped melon was delicious, the saltiness of the ham with the sweet melon was heaven. Then the burrata was fresh and yummy even if the tomatoes were cold and out of season.  Our entrees were the roasted half chicken and veal shank with polenta. Both were delicious and so filling. Our waiter was quick to ask if we needed anything. The manager came over to ask how our meal was, all in all delicious food. 

Cons- when we got out slice of bread, we never was asked if we wanted another, even as we watched the server come around and ask other tables. The chicken entree was hot, the veal shank was pretty warm, but the polenta was cold and flavorless. Even with salt and pepper it was only delicious as a vehicle for the veal and the delectable sauce. And I love polenta!!! Our server was pleasant but overly efficient. When we were finished with our entrees but wanted to take the rest to go, he swept our plates off before we could explain we wanted to take the rest. He asked if we were finished and if the plates should go back.... when we said yes, he collected the plates before we even got a chance to say wait. He was very pleasant but rarely made eye contact and we felt rushed through our meal. We were in and out in 45 minutes, when we wanted to have a nice leisurely meal at a genuine Italian restaurant. 

All in all, I would go back, but knowing what to expect. And perhaps speak up more. The food is delicious, just don't expect super warm and inviting service from your server.
author: Heather R.

description: Mediocre at best. Service lacking. No contact from waiter for 15 minutes in arrival. Pasta with pesto over cooked and chicken breast with a charcoal flavor.  Drinks were standard. Wife had  pumpkin ravioli. Costco may have better ravioli. Atmosphere was cozy and had a jazz band playing which salvaged the meal.
author: Aaron C.

description: Great food & atmosphere. Very happy with the ravioli bolognese. Chef made my father a special dish that was not on the menu at no additional charge. We will continue to stop by Fior d'Italia whenever we are in SF!
author: Cezanne B.

description: Two stars is pretty giving considering the service we received here. Went in for my 21st birthday and we had reservations for our group at 9:15 but what they didn't tell us was that the kitchen closes at 9:30. The moment we walked in the waiter was very rude. Pressuring us to order and making snide comments. The waiter stood over one of my guests as he was reading the menu and was reminding us that the kitchen was closing in 2 minutes. He was incredibly rude, probably the worse service I've ever received. The food was not awful but I have had better. The gnocchi was squishy and overdone. When the check came the waiter didn't ask to split it, he put the whole check on one bill and notified us that the 20% tip was included. When we paid part with cash and part with card he POCKETED THE CASH AS EXTRA TIP, and then charged the rest of the bill to the cards. When we talked to the manager he was not apologetic or helpful whatsoever. The whole ordeal was frustrating, time consuming, and disrespectful. Would not go again.
author: Alora B.

description: The experience in this place was great. The attention excellent, the food amazing. I would definitely go back many times.
author: Esteban Q.

description:
If I were to go back here it would be to try more of the food. Everything that came out looked stellar and everything we got was quite good. I had the steak, it was prepared perfectly and served with a nice sauce. My fiance had the lasagna- the sauce was phenomenal. We shared the burrata salad. While the cheese was great quality, there could have been a bit more for $16. Presentation was nice on all the dishes. 
The space is lovely. Old and beautiful with lots of windows and tables that are not too close together. Soft music, nice lighting. Fair prices overall, IMO

That's the good. What was just ok? The service. They seemed a bit busy but the service did not give the idea of fine dining that is boasted on their website. It wasn't bad, but it was minimal. No lobby, so people waiting are standing in the dining room.

The bad? I pay attention to the details. Ladies room needed attention. Front door left open leaving us a little too cold. Glassware set on our table was dirty. Lipstick. On multiple glasses. That shakes my confidence in the cleanliness of a place. One glass? OK. 2 or more..eww. Finally, though it seems that the locals that frequent the place are get that this is a nicer restaurant, it is close enough to the Wharf that there are tourists that show up with 3 messy kids and a screaming baby looking like they just got out of a hot yoga class. Not the restaurants fault but when you are paying $50+ pp, having kids going in and out of the restaurant and a wailing baby is a no go.

We might try this place again but it is not on the top of our list.
author: Disco B.

description:
Update.. accidentally reviewed the wrong location. 
Ate here some time ago and was planning to go back soon which is why I bookmarked the site.. love this place and the people... And of course the Food.. sorry for the mixup.. see you very soon..
author: Charles H.

description:
I continue to adore Fior d'Italia despite a couple of problematic NY steaks during prior visits. I've simply had too many good experiences to let a couple of not so good steaks get in the way of coming back. It's my home away from home.

We came here for Thanksgiving and had an absolutely lovely evening. In lieu of the steak, we shared the Bucatini Amatriciana, a spicy pasta dish we hadn't tried before. My partner isn't as fond of spicy dishes as I am but we both thought it was delicious. I actually ate my entire half, a rarity since I have a very dainty appetite. I think I requested extra bread (which, BTW is delicious and hearty) to sop up the remaining sauce.

I broke my toe yesterday and the cocktails were the perfect painkillers. Thank you Gio and the rest of the bartending team as always for the two-fisted lime drops. 

Thanks also to Gianni. It was a pleasure to meet you tonight, however briefly. I spotted your name on your chef's jacket and recognized it instantly. You were very kind during our brief interaction.

The service was awesome, as always. I got at least two or three hugs before leaving :D
author: Maya B.

description:
Had dinner at Fior D'Italia last night, and as always, great experience! 

The dinning room is so pretty & warm, great service and food delicious --and I'm Italian!  

Last night we had a special treat, Jelly Roll Jazz was playing lively 30's& 40's music -so all around what a great evening!  Grazie Fior D'Italia
author: nicole c.

description:
6:000pm reservations  -.  Table for 11

FIOR 'd Italiia is considered​  "the Oldest Italian Restaurant in America", located on the ground floor of the San Remo Hotel  on Mason St., Known for their Authentic Northern Italian cuisine.

Since we were a pretty good size group, and it was a week night, they had their private room available to us for dining   We came to celebrate my brother-in-law's birthday.  It had been awhile since I've visited Fior 'd Italia, maybe 5 years, but alot has changed, mainly the layout and the menu.  Still the warm, welcoming vibe was still there. 

While the servers were busy giving us waters, menus, complementary rustic bread with olive oil and balsamic, they brought a couple of bottles of Italian Chianti Wine for the table, at my sister's suggestion.  Next came the hot and cold appetizers, italian-style on platters 
Immediately next we all enjoyed a Caesar's salad, followed by a cup of Minestrone soup. The servers were very attentive, friendly, quick and helpful.  We all had various entrees which ranged from steaks, risotto, seafood, pasta and poultry dishes.  I was fortunate to have ordered their fabulous Multi layered Lasagna, layered with pasta, prosciutto with cheese in a ragu sauce. It was delish!  Portions were perfectly right size  Such a classy place, and the food shines.

Overall, it was a great experience!  Good to rediscover a San Francisco institution and still be able to recommend it. We were very happy with our outstanding service.

To End our celebratory dinner, my sister had picked up the infamous Yasukochi's Coffee Crunch Cake, in Japantown. The server helped with cutting, candle, and singing, like all Italians do. I can't even describe how DELICIOUS the cake was.  Every morsel was devoured. Not a trace was left.

Definitely a good night.
author: Janet T.

description: One of the best dining experiences I've ever had in San Francisco, and I'm a native! The food was excellent, the service was extraordinary, entertainment superb, and the manager Lalo made sure we had one of the best services ever!!! His staff Alberto, Antonio and Israel were very attentive, but none could compare to the attention Lalo himself provided! Thanks again Lalo for a wonderful experience, can't wait to spread the word!!!!
author: Mr. W.

description: We had a delicious dinner here. The bucatini is phenomenal with just the perfect amount of spice. The potatoes are also cooked to perfection you won't find much better. Finally we highly recommend the Panna cotta for desert. Also our server Michael was fantastic!
author: Anant V.

description:
I'm in love with Fior d'Italia! From the ambiance, to the delicious food, to the charismatic waiters, I loved it all! 

When you walk in you are greeted the host you directs you to your table. After being seated, you are given a loaf of bread to eat with olive oil and balsamic vinegar. This is probably my favorite thing about Italian restaurants, the free bread! My dad and I got the clams and mussels as our starter which was amazing. A little pricey for the amount given, so I'm not quite sure I would get it again. It would be an understatement to say dipping my bread into the mussel and clam juice was divine. 

The pasta was out of this world! I got the tagliatelle with the bolognese sauce. I have to say I have had comparable pastas for cheaper, but the ambiance of the restaurant really bumped the rating up for me from a 4 to a 5.

While on the pricier side, I would definitely suggest this restaurant to anyone who is looking for some classic Italian cuisine.
author: Kaitlyn F.

description:
My wife and I were visiting from out of town and this restaurant was in the area we were staying at for the weekend. It was established in 1886 and is still around, so they had to be doing something right. We were able to make last minute reservations on a Saturday night and received a nice table. 

Ambiance:
White tablecloth tables in a large dining room, which was connected to another room that had a nice bar with the local Warriors game on the TV. You could tell the place had character, with photos dating back to decades ago. There were lots of large parties and the staff seemed to know some of the guests, which made the environment very welcoming. 

Service:
The staff starting from the host to the server to the bus boys were all pleasant. Our server was friendly, energetic, and took all our requests with a smile. However, some gripes I have are that it took almost 10 minutes once we sat down to have someone come to our table to greet us, pour some water, and ask for drinks. Also, throughout the meal our server did not come check in on us from the time we got our food to when we were pretty much finished. Not a huge deal because we were not in dire need of anything, but it would have been frustrating if we were trying to track them down for something. 

Food:
For appetizers, we ordered a Caesar salad paired with the garlic bread bruschetta topped with heirloom tomatoes. They were both stellar and I would definitely get them again. The two entrees we ordered were the lasagna bolognese and tri-color pasta mix (penne pesto, tortellini stuffed with chicken, potato gnocchi). The lasagna bolognese was fresh out of the oven and just as I would expect with lots of flavor and extremely filling. The other pasta plate left you wanting more. The flavors were a bit bland, but of the 3 choices the penne pesto was the tastiest. 

Final Thoughts:
Overall we had a good experience. I wish the entrees were more flavorful, however, the appetizers were great and the service left us satisfied. I'd be curious to see how their other entrees taste, which means I'd try this place out again if given the choice.
author: Michael S.

description: The New York steak was so tender I could cut it with a butter knife. It was cooked to perfection and everything we ate from the appetizers to the desserts were like nothing I've ever tasted before. Pure heaven! Customer service was superb!!
author: Shannon T.

description:
The ambiance is nice. 
Good wine selection
Their artisan type sourdough bread was delicious! 
My noodles in pasta were good but then I hit a firm/stuck noodle clump. Ick. 
But all in all it was really good. 
Visit was Feb 2017 on a Saturday after Giants Fan Fest. 

Manager Lalo was very attentive to our needs. Will be back again!
author: Solo S.

description:
Wandered in to Fior d'Italia last night for an adult bevie at the bar and ended up ordering a meal.

The man behind bar was very friendly, bright and attentive.

I love wood and Fior d'Italia offers a wonderful wooden bar, booths for dining, everything that makes this establishment special and, what is favored by yours truly, very old-school approach to service and dining.

I ordered the Romana salad that was good but easily replicated in many restaurants across this great city.

I know not why but bucatini is my favorite pasta and offered with an Amatraciana sauce makes it a must have for me. I was not disappointed.

I am a fan of this old-school establishment, friendly front-of-house staff and proudly prepared and plated old-world food.
author: Jay D.

description:
I always make it a point to come here when I am in town. This is one of the OLDEST Italian joints in the city. The staff is incredibly nice and attentive. There is live music weekend nights as well. Wine flows all night as you take in the beauty of the old building.
ALWAYS try to get the lasagna; there's something magical that they put in there. I can't quite put my finger on it. There is never a wait here; I've walked in every time I come and they are super inviting each time.
author: Tika O.

description: Homemade pasta...you should definitely try. We had the calamari too (top notch). Plus, valet parking makes life so much easier. We arrived early (5ish) and not too busy, but picked up by dinner time. The Host greeted me in the most hospitable way and instantly made me feel at home. They also have photos throughout of their early days. Such a welcoming place with great history.
author: Sarah B.

description: Delicious food, June 13, 2018 we went to Fior d'Italia for dinner.  I ordered the lamb gluten free with carrots, potatoes and asparagus.  I was not disappointed.  The best Italian dinner I have had in 30 years!  And North Beach Rythm band with Jessica King singing topped the evening off, very good Jazz, Blues and Swing.  Come and join them again when they are here, you won't be disappointed especially if Jess is singing!!!  I will be back soon.
author: Car B.

description:
There was no way my wife would let us go to the North Beach/Telegraph Hill area again for Italian food.  The last time we were there, we parked far, far away in a different zip code because there was no parking available.  Then when we arrived to the restaurant, my daughter was frightened to see a waitress that looked just like her dreaded 4th grade math teacher.  So, when Fior d'Italia was recommended to me as a good Italian restaurant, I knew that I would have to bring my family.  

Parking was a cinch!  We found a parking spot across the street from the restaurant.  I had made reservations at 7:30 PM.  The restaurant was located in a small hotel.  We walked in and were seated immediately.  It was a nice comfortable place.  We ordered a Calamari in Cesta for the daughter.  My wife ordered a Linguine con Vongole, and I ordered the Linguine con Polpette.  

The Calamari in Cesta came out first.  The calamari was served inside a coffee filter, and came with a lemon, cocktail and tartar sauce.  The Calamari was very good.  My wife and I had to rescue the daughter from ingesting too much cholesterol inducing squid.  The Linguine Con Vongole was another winner.  It was made with fresh clams.  The sauce was perfect.  My wife enjoyed it and almost did not want to share it with me.  The Linguine con Popette was also good.  It came with tomato sauce and two meatballs.  The meatballs were different.  They looked more like flying saucers; like someone had sat on my meatballs.  But, I liked it.  

Service was good throughout our meal.  They refilled our glasses with water and frequently checked up on us.  Even the host (manager?) came to check up on us.  

Fior d'Italia is a nice place!  I like it.  It is nice that I don't have to go to that other place with no parking!  I hope to be back one day.
author: Phil Y.

description:
You have to, have to, have to have Italian food when in North Beach.  But you must choose very carefully.

I had a few places on my list to try and this one was in walking distance from Cobb's Comedy Club.  

Its a cute quintessential, cozy Italian restaurant.  There was a lot of people enjoying themselves at tables but they had two seats just for me and my husband.  I want to add that most of the other patrons were quite the cast of characters.  

They have outstanding cocktails.  On the other side of the dining room is a great bar too.  We didn't get to stay in it long because the restaurant closed as we paid the bill but walked through and it seemed like a fun bar to hang out at.

The cocktails of note were the Trixie Cocktail and the Capri Cocktail.  The Capri had Lemon Cello and Vodka.  Scrumptious!

I cant pass up a chance to have lamb and boy was I happy that I had it here.  It was the Rack of Lamb with the smoothest mashed potatoes ever.  The sauce was made from the gods of sauces.  It was perfect.

My husband had the Oso Buco.  I couldn't help but steal bites from his plate and he did mine.  We essentially had two entrees.  The food was unbelievable.

While the food was fantastic, the service was wonderful.  The best wait service for a first time visit we have had in a long time.  You can tell they really enjoy being here and sharing in the love of food and cocktail with their clientele.  The whole experience was divine.

For dessert we had a Tiramisu Cocktail.  Could it get any better!?  NO!

Go to a show, walk over here and thoroughly enjoy yourself.
author: Ivy R.

description: I love this place with all my heart. This is one of those rare restaurants in San Francisco that transport you back to another era and I dig that! The Bucatini Amatriciana is heaven on earth and the reason this restaurant will forever have a special place in my heart. The veal piccata and veal scallopine are also delicious. You can also eat in their very nice bar and on certain nights they have live jazz. I always leave here happy.
author: Dana S.

description:
Stopped by for dinner here around 8 pm with my boyfriend after biking the Golden Gate Bridge on 4th of July. We were quite underdressed in our athletic gear while most folks at Fior d'Italia were in nicer clothes and seemed to be headed to the fireworks after dinner.

Nonetheless, we were seated quickly. Service wasn't the quickest but the food was delicious.

Our meal began with tasty bread with fragrant olive oil and balsamic vinegar, that reminded us of our trip to Italy last year. We ordered Calamari to start the meal. It came with generous portions of lemon which we appreciated, and the tartar and cocktail sauces were both good. The portion was also much larger than we expected.

For our main dishes, I got Eggplant Parmigiana while my boyfriend got Tortellini alla Panna, Tortellini stuffed with chicken. Both dishes were delicious and filling and we left happily stuffed with warm food after a cold and windy day of biking.

Prices are a little steep (Probably closer to $$$ than $$) but we definitely enjoyed the meal.
author: Anna M.

description:
So genuine and classy that I came here two nights in a row!  I randomly stopped in the first night because it was walking distance from my hotel.  I was with an old friend, and we had such a blast at the bar with hospitable and outgoing Gio that I brought another friend the next day for happy hour... and we ended up staying for dinner.  The bread with oil, vinegar, and Parmesan hit the spot while we waited for our salad and entrees.  

Truly a lovely experience due to the old-time-San Fran ambiance, amazing service, delicious food, AND noteworthy drinks.  This place is a popular spot during happy hour.  Gio mixed unique cocktails, and the tiramisu martini ended up being my favorite.  Good vibes all around!   Next time I'm in San Fran, I'll be at Fior d'Italia!  See you soon.
author: L K.

description: Everything was good: atmosphere, stuff, environment. But waiting for an order for 1 hour and 5 minutes is too much. Even for a city like San Francisco. Forget the high prices for small portions (again, it's San Francisco and plus North Beach area). Maximum acceptable waiting time should be no longer than 30 minutes, especially when it's your wife's birthday, even for the oldest Italian restaurant in America.
author: Ara A.

description:
We went here for dinner on a Saturday. We decided to sit at the bar as there were several large parties in the dining room with active children. Our appetizer was outstandjng. The melon with prosciutto. Well worth the price. I had a martini and my husband a beer-again delicious. Dinner, well, dinner was a bit disappointing. 

The food took about 45 mins and we had been told my chicken would take at least 20. My chicken arrived with vegetables. It looked delicious but was dry and a bit over cooked. My husband's steak was cooked correctly and he said it was good. My expectation for the prices was not exactly as hoped. The waiters are not as attentive as a restaurant of this "reputation" would expect. All in all only an ok experience that was expensive. The restaurants @ North Beach offer similar menus and prices with a bit better service and quality.
